transcript:
Therapist: You're making great progress in developing a new relationship with your thoughts and emotions, Emilio. As we wrap up our work on thought records today, I want to emphasize the importance of continuing to practice this skill regularly. The more you do it, the more natural it will feel, and the more you'll start to notice changes in your overall mood and behavior.

Patient: I definitely see the value in keeping up with the thought records. It's just a matter of making it a habit.

Therapist: Absolutely. And as we discussed earlier, setting aside a specific time each day and using reminders can be really helpful in building that habit. Before we move on to discussing the Pomodoro Technique and boundary setting, I want to check in on how you're feeling right now. How would you describe your current emotional state?

Patient: I'm feeling a bit tired, but also encouraged. It's helpful to have a plan for working on my perfectionism and self-critical thoughts.

Therapist: I'm glad you're feeling encouraged, even if you're also a bit tired. It's normal to feel some fatigue after doing this kind of emotional work. Let's shift gears a bit and talk about the Pomodoro Technique and boundary setting. You mentioned earlier that you've been trying to use these techniques, but it's been challenging to be consistent with them. Can you tell me more about what's been getting in the way?

Patient: I think part of it is just that I get caught up in what I'm doing and forget to take breaks or set boundaries. It's like I get tunnel vision and lose track of everything else.

Therapist: That's a really common experience, especially when we're working on tasks that require a lot of focus and concentration. One strategy that can be helpful is to build the Pomodoro Technique and boundary setting into your daily routine, so that they become more automatic. For example, you could set a timer for every 25 minutes, and when the timer goes off, that's your cue to take a break, regardless of what you're working on.

Patient: That could work. I like the idea of having a set time to take a break, rather than trying to remember to do it on my own.

Therapist: Exactly. And you can use the same principle for boundary setting. For example, you could set a boundary with yourself that you'll only check your email at certain times of day, or that you'll only work on a particular project for a set amount of time before taking a break. By building these techniques into your routine, they become more automatic and require less effort to maintain.

Patient: I like that idea. I think I could definitely set some boundaries around my email and work hours.

Therapist: That's great, Emilio. Remember, the key is to start small and build up gradually. Don't try to overhaul your entire routine all at once. Pick one or two boundaries to focus on, and practice them consistently until they become habit. Then you can add more boundaries as needed.

Patient: Okay, I can do that. I'll start with setting a boundary around my email and work hours, and then maybe add in some boundaries around my personal time as well.

Therapist: That sounds like a great plan. As you're working on building these habits, it can also be helpful to track your progress and celebrate your successes along the way. This could be as simple as making a note in your journal or on your calendar each time you successfully take a break or set a boundary. Over time, you'll start to see the progress you're making, and that can be really motivating.

Patient: I like the idea of tracking my progress. It's always nice to see how far I've come.

Therapist: Absolutely. And celebrating your successes, no matter how small they may seem, is a great way to build momentum and keep yourself motivated. Remember, every time you take a break or set a boundary, you're taking a step towards a more balanced and sustainable way of working and living.

As we wrap up our session today, I want to assign some homework to help you continue practicing the skills we've discussed. First, I'd like you to continue using the thought records, setting aside a specific time each day to reflect on your thoughts and emotions. Second, I'd like you to start implementing the Pomodoro Technique and boundary setting into your daily routine, starting with the boundaries we discussed around email and work hours. And third, I'd like you to track your progress and celebrate your successes along the way.

Patient: Okay, that all sounds good. I'll definitely keep up with the thought records and start working on the Pomodoro Technique and boundary setting.

Therapist: Great. Remember, the key is consistency and persistence. It's not about being perfect, but about making small, incremental changes over time. I'm confident that if you keep practicing these skills, you'll start to notice some real changes in your mood and overall well-being.

Before we end our session, I want to check in one more time on how you're feeling. How are you doing now?

Patient: I'm feeling good. Tired, but also motivated to keep working on this stuff. It's helpful to have a plan and some concrete strategies to work on.

Therapist: I'm glad to hear that, Emilio. It's normal to feel a bit tired after doing this kind of work, but it's also really encouraging to hear that you're feeling motivated and hopeful. Remember, you don't have to do this alone. I'm here to support you every step of the way.

Patient: Thanks, Nova. I appreciate all your help and support.

Therapist: You're welcome, Emilio. I'm really proud of the work you're doing, and I'm excited to see the progress you'll continue to make. Let's plan to meet again next week at our usual time. In the meantime, feel free to reach out if you have any questions or concerns.

Patient: Sounds good. I'll see you next week.

Therapist: Alright, take care of yourself, Emilio. Have a great rest of your day.

Session Summary:
- Main topics discussed:
  - Continued work on challenging perfectionism and building self-compassion
  - Reviewed and practiced thought records
  - Discussed strategies for making the Pomodoro Technique and boundary setting more consistent and integrated into daily life
  - Checked in on overall mood and progress with depression symptoms
- Techniques or exercises used:
  - Thought records (continued from previous sessions)
  - Pomodoro Technique (continued from previous sessions)
  - Boundary setting (continued from previous sessions)
  - Positive data log (continued from previous sessions)
  - Cognitive restructuring (continued from previous sessions)
  - Self-compassion breaks (introduced in this session)
- Homework assigned:
  - Continue using thought records, setting aside a specific time each day to reflect on thoughts and emotions
  - Start implementing the Pomodoro Technique and boundary setting into daily routine, starting with boundaries around email and work hours
  - Track progress and celebrate successes along the way
- Patient's progress, challenges, depression symptoms, and important personal details:
  - Patient reported feeling encouraged and motivated to continue working on perfectionism and self-compassion
  - Patient continues to struggle with consistency in using the Pomodoro Technique and boundary setting, but has a plan for building these habits
  - Depression symptoms include fatigue and feelings of overwhelm, but patient reported some improvement in these symptoms by the end of the session
- Core beliefs and intermediate beliefs:
  - Negative core belief: "I am not good enough and have to be perfect to be worthy."
  - Alternative core belief: "I am good enough and worthy, even when I'm not perfect."
  - Intermediate beliefs: "If I'm not perfect, people will reject me." "I have to be available all the time or people will think I don't care." "If I set boundaries, I'm a bad person."
- Plan for the next session:
  - Review homework, including thought records, Pomodoro Technique, and boundary setting
  - Continue exploring the role of perfectionism in patient's life and how it relates to core beliefs
  - Introduce additional techniques for challenging perfectionism and building self-compassion, such as mindful self-reflection and gratitude practice
  - Check in on patient's overall mood and progress with depression symptoms
